Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Adaptation to Long Term Environmental Unpredictability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This project investigates how subsistence strategies helped people in an arid region manage environmental risk and uncertainty. As aridification increases worldwide, it is important to understand the complex dynamics of local environments and knowledge systems over long timescales to help sustain human lifeways in arid zones. This is especially important for arable areas that are crucial for food production within arid regions. Archaeology informs the development of adaptive, resilient subsistence strategies by offering a deep-time perspective on how humans and the environment shaped contemporary landscapes. It also provides examples of the diverse ways that humans have interacted with the environment and dealt with environmental change. Despite traditional characterizations of drylands as static, uninhabitable, and agriculturally marginal, many arid zones have changed dramatically over time and have long histories of human occupation. This project builds on recent studies contending that arid lands are fluctuating landscapes with rich natural resources. This research focuses on human subsistence strategies, which are important for climate resiliency because subsistence is central to risk management systems and deeply tied to shifting climate and environmental conditions. The project will generate research partnerships building upon a multi-year collaborative field project that has trained both doctoral and undergraduate students. <br/><br/>Risk management is typically embedded in cultural practice and includes strategies like diet diversification, food storage, intensified resource production, or resource exchange. This project will examine how these types of risk buffering techniques operated within a hyperarid coastal landscape, which has been impacted for millennia by El NiÃ±o climatic fluctuations and tectonic activity. The project focuses on a small valley with a long-term occupation history. The researchers will analyze sediment samples and various archaeological plant and animal remains to determine local subsistence practices and the exploitation of coastal desert microenvironments during the occupation. The work will incorporate microbotanical analyses into this comprehensive subsistence reconstruction to investigate how coastal villagers managed and procured diverse wild and agricultural resources. The project will use geoarchaeological analyses of sediments to create a paleoenvironmental record for the region, and this will contextualize risk management and resource procurement within a long-term history of local environmental change. The project will contribute to understanding how different subsistence systems relate to experiences of risk in arid regions worldwide.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The archaeological project supported by this award investigated how subsistence strategies helped people living in arid environments manage their vulnerability to environmental risk and uncertainty. Evidence of how people in the past interacted with their environments (including with risky climate fluctuations) can inform discussions about climate resiliency and food production amidst contemporary global climate change. For this project, Co-PI Camille Weinberg studied human-climate-environment interactions at Jahuay, a shoreline fishing village on Peru's desert coast. Jahuay was occupied approximately 2000 years ago during a time of regional social change and transition associated with the broader Paracas cultural period (approx. 800 BCE-200 CE) on the southern coast. In coastal Peru, predictable seasonality and semi-predictable El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) climate events of varying severity frequently affect agricultural landscapes and marine and onshore resources that were exploited by pre-Hispanic people. To understand how people dealt with risks of food scarcity associated with dynamic climate conditions in this desert, Weinberg studied subsistence remains- specifically of plants and marine shellfish- that were left by Jahuay's residents and recovered in recent archaeological excavations of the village.

Weinberg identified the types of plant and shellfish resources that people used at Jahuay, the environments the resources came from, and the types of subsistence activities (e.g., farming, fishing, foraging) undertaken by the community. Her methods included identifying microscopic plant remains (phytoliths) from Jahuay to detect additional plant types that were not preserved as larger remains. This award also funded expert identification of charcoal remains by Dr. Luis Huaman Mesia (Laboratorio de Palinologia y Paleobotanica at the Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia), which contributed additional evidence for plant use. From these datasets, Weinberg inferred risk management characteristics of the local subsistence strategy that were suited to maintain consistent resource availability at Jahuay. Findings demonstrate that the fishing community exploited wild resources from microenvironments within the desert that were accessible from the village's shoreline location. Choosing storable foods and cultivating some plants may have increased the community's self-sufficiency and flexibility during climate changes. Exchanging for domesticated food crops with inland farming communities supported diet diversification and buffered risk by maintaining social relationships. The findings emphasize that this coastal desert environment was resource-rich and that communities still relied on many wild resources even though cultivated food crops were available.

To relate subsistence at Jahuay to local landscape history, award funds also contributed to developing a new local paleoenvironmental record for the mouth of the Topara Valley where Jahuay is located. Under the supervision of PI Arlene Rosen, the Co-PI used geoarchaeology techniques to analyze sediments sampled from the valley at the Environmental Archaeology Laboratory at the University of Texas at Austin. Methods included phytolith analysis to reconstruct landscape history and vegetation. Ages of associated charcoal and sediment samples submitted to professional laboratories (National Ocean Sciences Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (NOSAMS) Facility, Luminescence Dating Facility at Victoria University of Wellington) for absolute dating show that this long-term paleoenvironmental record extends back over 11,000 years. The findings show changes to climate conditions and the local landscape (e.g., channel incision) in this valley during the Holocene Epoch.

Existing archaeological research into the broader Paracas period on the southern coast has provided important findings related to elite mortuary contexts, craft goods, and monumental sites. This Jahuay case study contributes much-needed evidence about non-elite lifeways, subsistence practices, fishing communities, and shoreline sites. The project addresses fundamental archaeological questions about subsistence transitions and ways in which people gradually committed to agriculture in different global regions. Methodologically, the project demonstrates the value of employing multiple botanical methods, and particularly microbotanical methods, at regional coastal sites to improve detection of archaeological plant remains. The paleoenvironmental record produced by this project is the first available for this valley and can inform future archaeological, geologic, and paleoclimatic research on regional environmental history.

This study built on a multi-year collaborative field project at Jahuay that was co-directed by the Co-PI, Jo Osborn (University of Michigan), and Peruvian archaeologist Lic. Kelita Perez Cubas. The Jahuay project trained two PhD students (Osborn and the Co-PI) and established lasting research collaborations between Peruvian and American researchers. Fieldwork salvaged vulnerable and disappearing archaeological data from Jahuay, which is undergoing continued looting and site degradation. Dozens of Peruvian archaeology students were trained during fieldwork, which also provided field experience for early-career American archaeology graduate students. Laboratory phases of this project trained the Co-PI in multiple laboratory methods and analyses of archaeological datasets. Future publications are planned to further disseminate the research findings, which have been published in the scholarly journal, The Holocene.
